Think of it like a digital painting. You start with a canvas (the Background Map). Then you add transparent sheets (Layers) on top. On each sheet, you draw your features (Markers, Lines, and Polygons). This separation keeps your data organized.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Level 1: Managing Your Map
These are the global settings that control your entire map.


Map Properties

Title & Description: Give your map a name and context.
Initial View: Set the default zoom level and center point.

Import Data (Global)

Click the “Upload data” button (⬆️).
Supports formats like .geojson, .gpx, .kml, and .osm.
This will create a new layer for the imported data.


Permissions & Sharing

Define who can see and edit your map.
Secret Links: Generate unique URLs for anonymous viewers or contributors.
Editors: Grant editing rights to specific OSM users.
Embed Options: Get the <iframe> code to place your map on a blog or website.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Level 2: Working with Layers
Layers are containers for your features. They help you organize and style data in bulk.

Purpose: Group similar objects.

Example: A layer for “Cafes,” another for “Bus Stops.”

Layer Properties:

Name: Rename the layer for clarity.
Color: Set a default color for all features in the layer.
Icon Shape/Symbol: Set a default icon for all markers.

Data Management:

Import: Add data directly into a specific layer.
Export: Download just that layer’s data.
Show/Hide: Toggle layer visibility on the map.








Tip


Organizing features into layers is key to creating a clean and understandable map, especially for complex projects.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Level 3: Objects - The Marker
A Marker represents a single point of interest (POI).
How to Create:

Select the marker tool (📍) from the toolbar.
Click on the map where you want to place the marker.
The editing panel will open.

Key Properties:

Name & Description: Add a title and detailed info. The description supports Markdown for formatting!
Color: Override the layer’s default color.
Icon Symbol: Choose a unique symbol to represent the feature.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Level 4: Objects - The Polyline
A Polyline is an ordered series of points connected to form a line.
How to Create:

Select the polyline tool.
Click on the map to add vertices (points).
Double-click on the last point to finish drawing.

Use Cases:

Roads, paths, or trails.
Bus routes.
River courses.

Key Properties:

Name & Description
Stroke Color & Width: Control the line’s appearance.
Dash Style: Make it a solid, dashed, or dotted line.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Level 5: Objects - The Polygon
A Polygon is a closed shape used to represent an area.


How to Create:

Select the polygon tool.
Click to add vertices for the boundary.
Click back on the first point to close the shape.

Use Cases:

Park boundaries.
Building footprints.
Neighborhood zones or districts.

Key Properties:

All polyline properties (stroke, etc.).
Fill Color: The color inside the shape.
Fill Opacity: How transparent the fill is.


The key difference between a polyline and a polygon is that a polygon is a closed area with a ‘fill’. This allows you to color in areas like parks or lakes, which is controlled by the fill color and opacity settings.

Mapping for Impact: KKN uMap Project
Community Service Projects with uMap in Indonesian Villages



Project Pages

Gumelem Wetan
Derik




The Goal: From Data to Action
Today, we’ll explore practical community service ideas for villages in Indonesia using uMap.

We will focus on creating thematic maps that visualize specific community needs.
These maps help village leaders, NGOs, and residents make better decisions.
uMap is the perfect tool for this—it’s free, easy to use, and builds on top of OpenStreetMap data.







Note


Remember: uMap is for creating custom map layers. It does not edit the official OpenStreetMap database. It’s a visualization tool.








graph LR

    style A fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style E fill:#9f9,stroke:#333







Welcome. The focus of this session is on impact. We’re going to take raw data and turn it into a powerful tool for community development using uMap. Think of it as telling a story with a map, a story that can lead to real change in a village.




Theme 1: Infrastructure & Governance
Mapping a village’s core assets helps with planning, maintenance, and administration.
“Peta Aset & Batas Desa”

Public Facilities: Map schools, mosques, health posts (Posyandu), and the village office (Kantor Desa).
Asset Maintenance: Track street lights, water pumps, and public toilets. Use colors to show status (e.g., Green for ‘Working’, Red for ‘Broken’).
Community Boundaries: Draw polygons for Hamlet (Dusun) and Neighborhood (RT/RW) borders to reduce disputes.

Impact: Provides a visual dashboard for the village government to manage assets and plan budgets (Dana Desa).



Theme 1: Infrastructure & Governance (other ideas)
Village Infrastructure Mapping

Map roads, paths, bridges, and public facilities (schools, mosques, health posts (posyandu), trash collection points).
Highlight areas needing repair or improvement.
Use layers to show accessibility for vehicles vs. foot traffic.
Impact: Helps villagers navigate important facilities; supports village planning (perencanaan desa).




Theme 2: Safety & Environment
Visualizing risks and resources can save lives and protect the local environment.
“Desa Siaga Bencana & Lestari”

Disaster Preparedness: Map flood-prone areas (rawan banjir), landslide zones, evacuation routes, and safe gathering points (titik kumpul).
Water & Sanitation: Identify wells, public taps, and also areas with poor drainage or illegal waste dumps.
Environmental Watch: Plot locations of riverbank erosion, illegal logging, or community reforestation projects.

Impact: Empowers the village disaster taskforce (Satgas) and supports public health campaigns (e.g., dengue fever prevention).






Tip


In the marker popups for evacuation points, add the contact number of the Hamlet Head (Kepala Dusun)!






Theme 2: Safety & Environment (other ideas)
Disaster Preparedness Maps

Map flood-prone zones, landslide areas, or evacuation routes.
Add safe shelters and community gathering points.
Provide villagers with printed or mobile-accessible maps for emergencies.

Map of: Fire-risk zones (rumah panggung, kebun kering), Nearest fire stations or call numbers, Evacuation routes, Open gathering spaces (lapangan, GOR), Landslide-prone areas (rawan longsor), Flood evacuation points
Impact: Supports BPBD, village disaster taskforce (Satgas Bencana), and education for villagers.

Water & Sanitation Mapping

Identify wells, water sources, and distribution points.
Mark areas with poor sanitation or waste disposal sites.
Help NGOs or local government prioritize clean water projects.
Impact: Useful for sanitation programs, NGO water projects, and health campaigns.

Environmental & Biodiversity Mapping

Plot forests, rivers, and biodiversity hotspots.
Identify illegal logging or waste dumping areas.
Support conservation efforts with visual evidence.



Waste Management & Environmental Map

Map of: Illegal dumping sites (TPS liar), Flood-prone drainage, Reforestation locations (perhutanan sosial), Recycling points, Riverbank erosion areas
Impact: Supports environmental policymaking and cleanup programs.




Theme 3: Economy & Livelihood
A map can be a powerful tool to boost the local economy and support farmers.
“Peta Ekonomi & Wisata Desa”

Agriculture: Map land use (rice fields, gardens), irrigation channels, and farmer group locations.
Local Business (MSME/UMKM): Plot home industries (e.g., snack producers), local cafes (warung), and workshops.
Tourism: Highlight attractions like waterfalls, homestays, or cultural sites to create a digital tourist guide.

Impact: Promotes local products, supports farmer cooperatives, and helps develop sustainable village tourism (Desa Wisata).

Theme 4: Social & Human Development
Mapping social data helps ensure that services reach the most vulnerable people.
“Peta Sosial & Pendidikan”

Health Access: Map homes of the elderly or persons with disabilities to guide health visits. Visualize the distance from homes to the nearest clinic.
Social Aid (Bansos): Use heatmaps to show concentrations of vulnerable households, ensuring aid is distributed fairly without revealing personal data.
Education: Create a “safe routes to school” map, highlighting dangerous crossings or unlit paths. Map digital dead zones where students struggle with online learning.

Impact: Supports transparency in aid distribution and helps improve access to health and education for all residents.



Theme 4: Social & Human Development (other ideas)
Health & Social Services Mapping

Map clinics, midwives, and traditional healers.
Add data on vaccination points or maternal health services.
Visualize underserved areas to guide outreach programs.

Education & Youth Engagement

Map schools, libraries, and informal learning centers.
Create a “safe routes to school” map for children.
Involve students in data collection as a learning project.

Health Risk Map

Identify:

Dengue mosquito hotspots (jangka DBD)
Waste accumulation spots
Areas with poor drainage
Home locations of elderly/disabled residents (for Posyandu Lansia)
Distance heatmaps to nearest health service

Impact: Supports Posyandu, Puskesmas, and public health efforts.




Theme 4: Social & Human Development (other ideas)


Educational Access Map

Map:

All schools and their student capacity
Students’ walking paths to school
Dangerous paths (no sidewalks, crossing rivers)
Internet/Wi-Fi signal levels in different areas
Community learning centers (PKBM, rumah belajar)

Impact: Supports village education programs, proposals for safer roads.



Digital Connectivity Map

Collect signal measurements using villagers’ phones:

Telkomsel, XL, Indosat signal strength by location
Wi-Fi hotspots (RT/RW Net, schools, warung)
Dead zones (blank spots)

Impact: Useful for proposing BTS towers, improving online schooling.




A Practical Workflow
From walking the village to sharing the final map.

Collect data: Walk the village with GPS-enabled phones, record points of interest.
Upload to uMap: Use categories (health, education, agriculture, etc.).
Community workshops: Teach villagers how to read and contribute to maps.
Share outputs: Print maps for local use, embed interactive maps on village websites or WhatsApp groups.


This is the process in a nutshell. Step 1 is about getting outside. Step 2 is organization. Step 3 is where the magic happens in uMap. And Step 4, crucially, is about getting the map into the hands of the people who can use it.




Start Your Project!
You have a powerful framework for making a real difference.

Choose a theme that is most relevant to your target village.
Engage the community: Talk to the village head and residents. Their input is essential.
Start small: Don’t try to map everything at once. A well-made map of one theme is better than a messy map of ten.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Outline

Problem Solving and Decision Making
Models of Cost, Revenue, and Profit
Introduction to Linear Programming
Problem Formulation
A Simple Maximization and Minimization Problem


Welcome! Today, we’ll explore how businesses use mathematical models to make better decisions. We’ll start with basic concepts like cost and profit, and then move on to a powerful tool called Linear Programming.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
What is a Mathematical Model?
A model is a simplified representation of a real-world situation. We use it to understand problems and test solutions before applying them in real life.


Deterministic Model

All inputs are known and fixed.
No uncertainty involved.
Example: Calculating the area of a room. You know the length and width for sure.


Stochastic (Probabilistic) Model

Some inputs are uncertain or random.
Involves probabilities.
Example: Forecasting next week’s sales. It might be affected by weather, holidays, or other random events.



Think of a deterministic model like a recipe: if you follow the instructions exactly, you get the same cake every time. A stochastic model is more like predicting the weather; you have good information, but you can’t be 100% certain. In business, we often have to choose between a simple, cheap model and a complex, expensive one. Sometimes, simpler is better!

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Austin Auto Auction
Let’s build a model to help an auctioneer set a starting bid for a used car.
The Goal: Set the starting bid (B) at 70% of the predicted final winning bid.
The Logic:

Start with the car’s original price (P).
Deduct for age (A): $800 per year.
Deduct for mileage (M): $0.025 per mile.


This is a classic example of a descriptive model. It takes known information and uses a formula to describe a situation—in this case, a car’s estimated value.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Building the Model
First, let’s write an equation for the expected winning bid:
\[
\text{Expected Bid} = P - 800A - 0.025M
\]
Now, we can build the full model for the starting bid (B), which is 70% of that value:
\[
\begin{aligned}
B &= 0.7 \times (\text{Expected Winning Bid}) \\
B &= 0.7 \times (P - 800A - 0.025M) \\
B &= 0.7P - 560A - 0.0175M
\end{aligned}
\]
This is our final model! It’s a simple linear equation.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Using the Model
Question: A car is 4 years old with 60,000 miles. Its original price was $12,500. What should the starting bid be?
Answer: We just plug the numbers into our model.

P = $12,500
A = 4 years
M = 60,000 miles

\[
\begin{aligned}
B &= 0.7(12,500) - 560(4) - 0.0175(60,000) \\
B &= 8750 - 2240 - 1050 \\
B &= \$5,460
\end{aligned}
\]
The auctioneer should set the starting bid at $5,460.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: What Are We Assuming?
Every model has assumptions. It’s important to know what they are!
What assumptions does this model make?

Only three factors matter: Original price, age, and mileage. It ignores things like the car’s condition, color, brand reputation, or if it’s a rare model.
Value loss is linear: It assumes a car loses exactly $800 in value every year and $0.025 every mile, forever. In reality, this isn’t true. A very old car could have a negative starting bid with this model, which doesn’t make sense!


This is a crucial lesson in modeling: models simplify reality. They are useful tools, but not perfect reflections of the world. Always question the assumptions behind a model.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Ponderosa Development Corp.
This company builds and sells one style of house. Let’s model its costs, revenue, and profit to find its break-even point—the number of houses it needs to sell just to cover its costs.


Key Financials (per house, per month):

Selling Price: $115,000
Variable Costs (per house):

Land: $55,000
Materials: $28,000
Labor: $20,000
Sales Commission: $2,000
Total Variable Cost: $105,000

Fixed Costs (per month):

Office lease, utilities, etc.: $5,000
Employee Salaries: $35,000
Total Fixed Cost: $40,000



Monthly Salaries



Employee
Salary




President
$10,000


VP, Development
$6,000


VP, Marketing
$4,500


Project Manager
$5,500


Controller
$4,000


Office Manager
$3,000


Receptionist
$2,000


Total
$35,000





Here we distinguish between two types of costs. Variable costs change with the number of houses built (like lumber). Fixed costs stay the same each month whether they sell 1 house or 10 houses (like the president’s salary).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: The Profit Model
Let ‘x’ be the number of houses sold in a month.
1. Revenue Function r(x): How much money comes in? \[
r(x) = 115,000x
\]
2. Cost Function c(x): How much money goes out? \[
c(x) = \underbrace{105,000x}_{\text{Variable Costs}} + \underbrace{40,000}_{\text{Fixed Costs}}
\]
3. Profit Function p(x): Revenue minus Cost. \[
\begin{aligned}
p(x) &= r(x) - c(x) \\
p(x) &= 115,000x - (105,000x + 40,000) \\
p(x) &= 10,000x - 40,000
\end{aligned}
\]

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Break-Even and Profit
What is the break-even point? Break-even is when profit is zero, or when Revenue = Cost. \[
\begin{aligned}
115,000x &= 105,000x + 40,000 \\
10,000x &= 40,000 \\
x &= 4
\end{aligned}
\] Ponderosa needs to sell 4 houses per month to break even.
What is the profit if they sell 12 houses? \[
p(12) = 10,000(12) - 40,000 = \$80,000
\] They would make an $80,000 profit.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Visualizing the Break-Even Point
A graph makes this crystal clear. Let’s plot the Cost and Revenue functions.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Introduction to Linear Programming (LP)
Linear Programming is a powerful mathematical tool used to find the best possible outcome (like maximum profit or minimum cost) in a given situation with certain limits or constraints.

Objective: The goal you want to maximize (e.g., profit) or minimize (e.g., cost).
Constraints: The rules or limitations you must follow (e.g., limited budget, time, or materials).
Feasible Solution: Any solution that satisfies all the constraints.
Optimal Solution: The feasible solution that gives the best possible value for the objective function.


Think of it like planning a diet. Your objective is to minimize calorie intake. Your constraints are that you must get enough protein, vitamins, and minerals, and you only have a certain budget for groceries. LP helps you find the perfect meal plan that meets all your needs while keeping calories as low as possible.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
The “Linear” in Linear Programming
So, what makes it “linear”?

Linear Functions: Each variable is simple (like x or y, not \(x^2\) or \(\sqrt{y}\)) and is multiplied by a constant.

Linear: 3A + 5B
Not Linear: 3A² + 5/B

Linear Constraints: These are linear functions restricted by inequalities or equalities.

Linear: 2x + 3y ≤ 50
Linear: A = 100


This linearity makes the problems solvable with efficient methods.

title: Management Decision Tools
Management Decision Tools
text:
LP Example 3: M&D Chemicals (Minimization)
Problem: M&D Chemicals needs to produce two products, A and B, at the lowest possible cost while meeting certain production demands.

Production Target: Total production of A and B must be at least 350 gallons.
Customer Order: Must produce at least 125 gallons of A.
Resource Limit: Only 600 hours of processing time are available.

Product A takes 2 hours/gallon.
Product B takes 1 hour/gallon.

Costs:

Product A costs $2/gallon.
Product B costs $3/gallon.


Objective: Minimize total production cost.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 3: M&D Chemicals Formulation
Let A = number of gallons of product A, and B = number of gallons of product B.
Minimize Cost: \[
\text{Min } 2A + 3B
\]
Subject to (s.t.): \[
\begin{array}{rll}
A &\ge 125 & \text{(Customer Demand)} \\
A + B &\ge 350 & \text{(Total Production)} \\
2A + B &\le 600 & \text{(Processing Time)} \\
A, B &\ge 0 & \text{(Non-negativity)}
\end{array}
\]
Optimal Solution: Produce 250 gallons of A and 100 gallons of B for a minimum cost of $800.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 3: Visualizing the M&D Solution
The valid production plans are in the shaded “Feasible Region”. The model finds the corner point in this region with the lowest cost.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
LP Example 4: Iron Works, Inc. (Maximization)
Problem: Iron Works makes two products from steel. They want to maximize their profit for the month.

Resource Limit: 2000 pounds of steel available.

Product 1 needs 2 lbs of steel.
Product 2 needs 3 lbs of steel.

Contract: Must make at least 60 units of Product 1.
Production Limit: Can make at most 720 units of Product 2.
Profits:

Product 1: $100 per unit.
Product 2: $200 per unit.


Objective: Maximize total profit.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 4: Iron Works Formulation
Let \(x_1\) = number of units of Product 1, and \(x_2\) = number of units of Product 2.
Maximize Profit: \[
\text{Max } 100x_1 + 200x_2
\]
Subject to (s.t.): \[
\begin{array}{rll}
2x_1 + 3x_2 &\le 2000 & \text{(Steel limit)} \\
x_1 &\ge 60 & \text{(Contract)} \\
x_2 &\le 720 & \text{(Production limit)} \\
x_1, x_2 &\ge 0 & \text{(Non-negativity)}
\end{array}
\]
Optimal Solution: From solver analysis, the best plan is to make 60 units of Product 1 and 626.67 units of Product 2.

title: Management Decision Tools
section: Example 4: Visualizing the Iron Works Solution
text:
Example 4: Visualizing the Iron Works Solution
Again, we can map out the “Feasible Region”. The goal is to find the corner point that gives the highest profit.

title: OSM and UMAP
section: The Goal: From Data to Action
text:
The Goal: From Data to Action
Today, we’ll explore practical community service ideas for villages in Indonesia using uMap.

We will focus on creating thematic maps that visualize specific community needs.
These maps help village leaders, NGOs, and residents make better decisions.
uMap is the perfect tool for this—it’s free, easy to use, and builds on top of OpenStreetMap data.







Note


Remember: uMap is for creating custom map layers. It does not edit the official OpenStreetMap database. It’s a visualization tool.








graph LR
    A[Community Need] --> B{Collect Data};
    B --> C[Create uMap];
    C --> D[Share Map];
    D --> E[Informed Action!];

    style A fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style E fill:#9f9,stroke:#333







Welcome. The focus of this session is on impact. We’re going to take raw data and turn it into a powerful tool for community development using uMap. Think of it as telling a story with a map, a story that can lead to real change in a village.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Theme 1: Infrastructure & Governance
Mapping a village’s core assets helps with planning, maintenance, and administration.
“Peta Aset & Batas Desa”

Public Facilities: Map schools, mosques, health posts (Posyandu), and the village office (Kantor Desa).
Asset Maintenance: Track street lights, water pumps, and public toilets. Use colors to show status (e.g., Green for ‘Working’, Red for ‘Broken’).
Community Boundaries: Draw polygons for Hamlet (Dusun) and Neighborhood (RT/RW) borders to reduce disputes.

Impact: Provides a visual dashboard for the village government to manage assets and plan budgets (Dana Desa).

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Theme 2: Safety & Environment
Visualizing risks and resources can save lives and protect the local environment.
“Desa Siaga Bencana & Lestari”

Disaster Preparedness: Map flood-prone areas (rawan banjir), landslide zones, evacuation routes, and safe gathering points (titik kumpul).
Water & Sanitation: Identify wells, public taps, and also areas with poor drainage or illegal waste dumps.
Environmental Watch: Plot locations of riverbank erosion, illegal logging, or community reforestation projects.

Impact: Empowers the village disaster taskforce (Satgas) and supports public health campaigns (e.g., dengue fever prevention).






Tip


In the marker popups for evacuation points, add the contact number of the Hamlet Head (Kepala Dusun)!

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Theme 3: Economy & Livelihood
A map can be a powerful tool to boost the local economy and support farmers.
“Peta Ekonomi & Wisata Desa”

Agriculture: Map land use (rice fields, gardens), irrigation channels, and farmer group locations.
Local Business (MSME/UMKM): Plot home industries (e.g., snack producers), local cafes (warung), and workshops.
Tourism: Highlight attractions like waterfalls, homestays, or cultural sites to create a digital tourist guide.

Impact: Promotes local products, supports farmer cooperatives, and helps develop sustainable village tourism (Desa Wisata).





graph LR
    subgraph "Village Tourism Layer"
        A(Attraction: <br> Waterfall)
        B(Homestay)
        C(Local Craft <br> Shop)
        D(Culinary: <br> Warung Kopi)
      
        A -- "nearby" --> B
        A -- "nearby" --> D
    end

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Theme 4: Social & Human Development
Mapping social data helps ensure that services reach the most vulnerable people.
“Peta Sosial & Pendidikan”

Health Access: Map homes of the elderly or persons with disabilities to guide health visits. Visualize the distance from homes to the nearest clinic.
Social Aid (Bansos): Use heatmaps to show concentrations of vulnerable households, ensuring aid is distributed fairly without revealing personal data.
Education: Create a “safe routes to school” map, highlighting dangerous crossings or unlit paths. Map digital dead zones where students struggle with online learning.

Impact: Supports transparency in aid distribution and helps improve access to health and education for all residents.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
A Practical Workflow
From walking the village to sharing the final map.

Collect data: Walk the village with GPS-enabled phones, record points of interest.
Upload to uMap: Use categories (health, education, agriculture, etc.).
Community workshops: Teach villagers how to read and contribute to maps.
Share outputs: Print maps for local use, embed interactive maps on village websites or WhatsApp groups.


This is the process in a nutshell. Step 1 is about getting outside. Step 2 is organization. Step 3 is where the magic happens in uMap. And Step 4, crucially, is about getting the map into the hands of the people who can use it.

title: OSM and UMAP
text:
Start Your Project!
You have a powerful framework for making a real difference.

Choose a theme that is most relevant to your target village.
Engage the community: Talk to the village head and residents. Their input is essential.
Start small: Don’t try to map everything at once. A well-made map of one theme is better than a messy map of ten.

title: Empowering Communities
section: The Essence of KKN (Community Work): Village Empowerment
text:
The Essence of KKN (Community Work): Village Empowerment
Community work is about empowering local communities, not just “fixing” problems.
It means enabling them to identify, address, and sustain their own development.


What is Village Empowerment?

Holistic Development: Focus on various aspects like education, health, economy.
Specific Community Focus: Understanding unique needs, culture, and governance structures.
Local Ownership: Ensuring projects are driven and sustained by the community itself.


How We Empower:

Introducing Technology/Innovation: Providing tools or methods to improve lives.
Social Engineering: Facilitating behavioral change and community cohesion.
Training & Education: Building skills and knowledge within the community.
Production Tools/Infrastructure: Supplying resources for economic growth or improved living.
Capital Access: Helping communities secure funding or micro-loans.



In this slide, emphasize that empowerment is about building capacity and local ownership, rather than merely providing handouts. Highlight the difference between short-term aid and sustainable development. Ask students to think about examples of each empowerment method.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Setting SMART Program Goals
Effective community programs require clear, actionable objectives.
The SMART framework ensures your efforts are focused and measurable.


SMART Principles

Specific: Clearly define what you want to achieve.
Measurable: Quantify your goals to track progress.
Achievable: Set realistic and attainable targets.
Relevant: Ensure goals align with community needs and your mission.
Time-bound: Establish a deadline for completion.


Practical Application

Clear Volumes: How many people, how many units, what scale?
Defined Goals: What is the desired outcome?
Schedules: Detailed timelines for activities.
Outputs: Tangible results of your work (e.g., 5 training sessions, 1 new irrigation system).
PICs (Person In Charge): Assign clear responsibilities for each task.








Tip


Example SMART Goal:
“Train 30 village youth in basic digital marketing skills within 3 months, leading to at least 5 new small businesses selling local products online.”




Encourage students to practice formulating a SMART goal for a hypothetical community project. Stress that well-defined goals are the foundation of successful project management. Discuss how ambiguity can lead to scope creep and disappointment.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Engaging the Community & Ensuring Sustainability
Community participation is the heart of successful, sustainable projects.
Without their involvement, initiatives often fade after your departure.


Steps for Engagement

Initial Consultation: Listen to their needs, not just tell them yours.
Joint Planning: Involve community members in decision-making.
Capacity Building: Train locals to manage and maintain projects.
Resource Mobilization: Encourage community contributions (time, labor, local materials).
Feedback Loops: Regularly gather input and adapt your approach.


Mermaid: Community Engagement Cycle





flowchart TD
    A["Identify Needs"] --> B("Joint Planning")
    B --> C("Implementation <br> (with local participation)")
    C --> D("Monitoring & <br> Evaluation")
    D --> E("Capacity Building <br> & Local Ownership")
    E --> F("Sustainability <br> & Replication")
    F --> A








Highlight that sustainability isn’t an afterthought but must be integrated from the very beginning. The flowchart visually represents the iterative nature of true community engagement. Emphasize that “leaving a legacy” means leaving a capable community, not just a physical structure.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Effective Communication with the Community
Communication is more than just talking; it’s about understanding and connection. Tailoring your communication is key to building trust and cooperation.

Respect Local Culture: Learn about customs, traditions, and social norms.
Understand Community Structure: Identify leaders, elders, youth groups, and their influence.
Use Appropriate Language: If possible, learn basic local phrases or use skilled translators.
Active Listening: Give genuine attention to their concerns and ideas.
Visual Aids: Use pictures, diagrams, or simple demonstrations for clarity.
Be Patient and Consistent: Building trust takes time and repeated, honest interactions.







Note


Cultural Sensitivity is Paramount:
A gesture or phrase that is harmless in your culture could be offensive elsewhere. Always observe and ask respectfully if you are unsure.




Share anecdotes or hypothetical scenarios where cultural insensitivity led to project failure. Stress that good intentions are not enough; understanding and adapting are crucial. Discuss non-verbal communication.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Team Management for Community Projects
A well-structured and collaborative team is essential for success.
Clearly defined roles and shared responsibilities prevent overlap and enhance efficiency.


Key Team Roles (Examples)

Project Lead: Overall strategy, external relations, problem-solving.
Facilitator/Trainer: Leads workshops, coordinates local activities.
Logistics Coordinator: Manages transport, materials, accommodation.
Documentation Specialist: Records progress, collects data, prepares reports.
Community Liaison: Primary point of contact with village members, cultural bridge.
Financial Administrator: Manages budget, expenses, procurement.


Principles for Effective Teams

Clear Roles & Responsibilities: Everyone knows their part.
Regular Communication: Daily check-ins, weekly reviews.
Mutual Support: Help each other out, celebrate successes.
Conflict Resolution: Address disagreements constructively and promptly.
Adaptability: Be ready to adjust plans based on field realities.



Emphasize that while roles are defined, flexibility is also key, especially in dynamic community work environments. Discuss the importance of team cohesion and morale, especially when facing challenges.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Leveraging Shared & Collaboration Tools
Modern tools can significantly streamline your project management and reporting. They enable real-time collaboration and secure information storage.


For Reporting & Documentation

Google Docs: Collaborative document creation, real-time editing for reports, proposals, meeting minutes.
Microsoft 365 (Word/Excel Online): Similar features for those familiar with the suite.
Etherpad / HackMD: Lightweight, real-time collaborative text editors, often open-source.


For Storage & Archiving

Google Drive: Cloud storage for all project files (photos, videos, documents, data). Easy sharing and access control.
Dropbox / OneDrive: Alternative cloud storage solutions with similar functionalities.
Version Control: Ensure important documents have version history to track changes.








Tip


Pro Tip:
Before going to the field, download critical documents for offline access in case of internet unavailability.




Discuss the importance of a naming convention for files and folders to maintain organization. Highlight the benefits of cloud storage for accessibility and backup, but also the need for offline readiness.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Communication Tools for the Field
Staying connected is vital for coordination, safety, and quick decision-making.
Choose tools that are reliable and accessible in rural settings.


Primary Communication Channels

WhatsApp: Group chats, quick updates, sending photos/videos.


Other Useful Tools

Email: For formal communication or sharing larger files.
Team Collaboration Platforms: Useful for internal team discussions, but require stable internet.



Emphasize establishing clear communication protocols: when to use which channel, expected response times, and emergency contact procedures. Discuss power bank solutions for keeping devices charged.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Task & Workflow Management
Organizing tasks and tracking progress keeps the team on schedule and accountable.
Adopt a framework that suits your project’s complexity and team’s preference.


Common Frameworks

Kanban Board: Visualizes workflow, tasks move through stages (To Do, In Progress, Done).

Tools: Trello, physical whiteboard with sticky notes.

Scrum Framework (Simplified): Iterative approach with short “sprints,” daily stand-ups, review meetings.

Focus: Adaptability, rapid feedback.

Gantt Chart: Project timeline showing tasks, dependencies, and progress over time.

Tools: Google Sheets, physical paper.



Simple Kanban Workflow





graph TD
    A["Backlog: <br> Ideas & To-Dos"] --> B{"To Do: <br> Ready for Work"}
    B --> C{"In Progress: <br> Currently Working"}
    C --> D{"Testing/Review: <br> Awaiting Feedback"}
    D --> E["Done: <br> Completed Tasks"]








Explain that for undergraduate community projects, a simple Kanban or even a well-organized spreadsheet can be highly effective. The key is consistency and visibility of tasks. Discuss the benefits of daily brief check-ins.

title: Empowering Communities
section: Kanban in Action: Visualizing & Managing Flow
text:
Kanban in Action: Visualizing & Managing Flow
Kanban is a highly visual system for managing work. It helps teams see their workflow, limit work in progress, and focus on completion.


Core Principles for Community Work

Visualize Workflow: Use a board (physical or digital) to show tasks from start to finish.
Limit Work in Progress (WIP): Avoid starting too many things at once. Focus on finishing!
Manage Flow: Track how tasks move. Where are the bottlenecks?
Make Policies Explicit: Clearly define “done” for each stage.
Improve Collaboratively: Regularly discuss what works and what doesn’t.


Practical Steps for Your Team

Set up Your Board: Create columns: e.g., “Ideas/Backlog,” “To Do,” “Doing,” “Done.”
Create Task Cards: Write each task on a separate card (sticky note or digital).
Pull System: Only move a card to “Doing” when there’s capacity (respect WIP limits).
Daily Check-ins: Briefly review the board: What’s stuck? What can we move forward?
Focus on “Done”: The goal is to move cards to the “Done” column as quickly as possible.



Emphasize the simplicity and flexibility of Kanban. It doesn’t require complex software; a whiteboard and sticky notes work perfectly. Highlight how limiting WIP helps avoid multitasking and ensures quality. Ask students for ideas on how they might visualize tasks for a specific community project.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Simple SCRUM for Community Projects
SCRUM provides a structured, iterative approach, ideal for projects with evolving needs.
It emphasizes short work cycles, regular feedback, and team autonomy.


Simplified Roles

Product Owner (Project Lead): Defines project goals, prioritizes tasks.
Scrum Master (Team Facilitator): Helps the team follow SCRUM, removes obstacles, keeps meetings focused.
Development Team (Project Team): Self-organizing group responsible for completing the work.


Key Activities (Ceremonies)

Sprint Planning: At the start of each “Sprint” (e.g., 1 weeks), the team plans what to achieve.
Daily Scrum (Stand-up): 15-minute daily meeting: What did I do yesterday? What will I do today? Any blockers?
Sprint Review: At Sprint end, demonstrate completed work, gather feedback.
Sprint Retrospective: Team reflects on the Sprint: What went well? What can we improve next time?








Note


Why Consider Simple SCRUM?
It’s excellent for projects where you need to adapt quickly based on community feedback.
The short Sprints allow for continuous learning and adjustment, reducing risks.




Clarify that this is a simple, adapted version of SCRUM. The goal isn’t strict adherence to all rules, but to benefit from its core principles: transparency, inspection, and adaptation. Stress the value of daily stand-ups for quick coordination and problem-solving.

title: Empowering Communities
section: Anticipating Uncertainty: Preparing for the Unexpected
text:
Anticipating Uncertainty: Preparing for the Unexpected
Community work often takes you into unpredictable environments.
Proactive planning for potential challenges is crucial.

Weather Contingencies: Heavy rain, extreme heat, or floods can disrupt plans.

Plan: Alternative indoor venues, rain gear, rescheduling protocols.

Internet/Power Problems: Expect unreliable connectivity and electricity.

Plan: Offline materials, power banks, printed copies, satellite communication options.

Logistical Issues: Vehicle breakdowns, road closures, material delays.

Plan: Backup transport, alternative routes, buffer time in schedules.

Health & Safety: Minor injuries, illness, remote medical access.

Plan: First aid kits, emergency contacts, knowledge of nearest health facilities.








Warning


“Expect the Unexpected”
Always have a Plan B (and maybe a Plan C). Being flexible and resourceful is a core skill in community engagement.




Encourage a mindset of preparedness without paranoia. Discuss creating an emergency contact list for the team and local authorities. Emphasize that “uncertainty” isn’t failure, but a natural part of working in dynamic environments.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Handling Problems Effectively
Challenges are inevitable. How you respond defines your team’s resilience and professionalism.
Approach problems with empathy, clear protocols, and decisive action.


Addressing Common Issues

Non-Participant Team Member:

Action: Private conversation, understand reasons, re-assign tasks, escalate if persistent.

Non-Supportive Community Members:

Action: Active listening, engage key influencers, demonstrate project benefits, seek mediation.

Project Delays:

Action: Re-evaluate priorities, communicate with stakeholders, adjust timelines realistically.



Critical Issue: Sexual Harassment






Important


Zero Tolerance Policy:
Any form of sexual harassment (verbal, physical, visual) is unacceptable.

Immediate Action: Ensure the victim’s safety.
Clear Reporting: Establish a confidential reporting mechanism for both team members and community.
Support: Provide support to the victim.
Consequences: Implement appropriate disciplinary actions for the perpetrator. Your responsibility is to create a safe environment.







This slide addresses sensitive topics. For sexual harassment, it’s crucial to be firm, clear, and proactive. Reiterate that this is non-negotiable. For other problems, stress the importance of documentation and learning from challenges. Acknowledge that these situations can be difficult but provide actionable steps.

title: Empowering Communities
text:
Conclusion: Making a Lasting Impact
Community work is a challenging yet profoundly rewarding experience.
Your dedication, preparation, and empathy can create a tangible, positive change.

Be Prepared: Plan meticulously, but be ready to adapt.
Engage Deeply: Build genuine relationships with the community.
Communicate Clearly: Ensure mutual understanding and respect.
Work as a Team: Support each other and share responsibilities.
Stay Resilient: Problems are opportunities for learning and growth.

Thank you for your commitment to empowering communities!

End with an inspirational and encouraging tone. Reiterate the key takeaways and reinforce the idea that their efforts truly matter. Open the floor for questions.

section: Emergency Response Map (“Peta Tanggap Darurat Desa”)

Emergency Response Map (“Peta Tanggap Darurat Desa”)

Map of: Fire-risk zones (rumah panggung, kebun kering), Nearest fire stations or call numbers, Evacuation routes, Open gathering spaces (lapangan, GOR), Landslide-prone areas (rawan longsor), Flood evacuation points
Impact: Supports BPBD, village disaster taskforce (Satgas Bencana), and education for villagers.

Water & Sanitation Mapping

Impact: Useful for sanitation programs, NGO water projects, and health campaigns.

Environmental & Biodiversity Mapping

Support conservation efforts with visual evidence.

text:
Waste Management & Environmental Map

text:
